docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Re ''The Importance of Knowing What the Doctor is Talking About'' (Personal Health, Jan. 30): Jane Brody's column about patient misunderstanding of physician communication overlooks how the problem is embedded in the language used to describe the problem. Sadly, our culture too often equates ''illiterate'' with ''dumb.'' Can you think of another service industry -- and like it or not, physicians provide a service -- that would call its customers ''illiterate'' for not understanding industry jargon? How many policies would an insurance expert sell if that term were used for customers who didn't understand actuarial tables?
docs.abstract: Garth Anderson letter on Jane Brody January 30 Personal Health column about communication between doctors and patients suggests that labeling patients medically illiterate does not help communication; Jeff Daniels letter on same column disagees with some examples of good communication; drawing (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: District Council 37, the city's largest union of municipal workers, announced yesterday that it had unionized more than 300 sales representatives and assistants who work in the MetroPlus health maintenance organization of the city's Health and Hospitals Corporation. District Council 37, which is part of the American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employees, announced that 149 of the workers voted to join District Council 37, while 64 voted to join a competing union, the Organization of Staff Analysts. For nearly two years, Local 1549, which represents clerical and administrative employees, had sought to organize the workers, who handle enrollment applications for people who use the H.M.O. within the city's hospital system. STEVEN GREENHOUSE

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: H.M.O. Representatives Unionize
